conclusion: Analyze the path of the light ray through the hemispherical shell to determine where it will exit or be reflected.
The hemispherical shell has inner radius R, outer radius R' = sqrt(2)R, and refractive index n = sqrt(2).
A beam of light parallel to the central symmetry axis OO' is incident on the outer surface of the hemisphere.
Find the critical angle at which total internal reflection occurs within the shell.
The critical angle theta_c for total internal reflection is given by sin(theta_c) = 1/n.
Light ray hitting the inner surface at an angle greater than 45 degrees will undergo total internal reflection.
The light ray will reflect back into the shell and continue traveling until it reaches the outer surface again.
The light-blocking plate must cover the region where light rays, after reflecting off the inner surface, would exit the shell.
The light rays will form a cone with the apex at the center of the shell due to symmetry.
The critical angle ensures that these rays will not exit the shell but will reflect back.
Determine the radius d of the light-blocking plate using the geometry of the cone formed by the reflected light rays.
The radius d of the light-blocking plate is 2R.
